climbs.name: Would You Like Fries With That
climbs.fa: Bryan Pletta & Karl Kiser & Noah Monagle, summer 2013

content.description: The crux is the last roof.  It may be slightly harder for shorter persons.  Be sure to have a one foot sling for the bolt on the first roof (rope drag if a sport draw).  If the third bolt of Bob's Big Boy is clipped at the start, a triple runner or equivalent is best to reduce rope drag.
content.protection: Gear and bolts.  Cams 0.3 to number #4 (double .4) and a few medium stoppers.  Better to have many two foot runners. Bolts and chains at the top.
content.location: The left wall to the right of Bob's Big Boy.  Clip the first bolts of Bob's Big Boy then trend right and straight up through the roofs.  Rap the route (be very careful if a 60m rope is used).

content.description: Starting in the 5.9 corner, head up and left past 3 bolts.  Follow a seam more or less straight up past a few gear placements. The head left again towards the arete passing 4 more bolts. Once on the arete some gear and another bolt take you to the top.
content.protection: 8 bolts and small gear to a bolted anchor. I don't remember using anything bigger than finger size (it has been awhile) so if you carry up to a #1 camalot you should be fine.
content.location: The furthest left route on the wall. Starting in the 5.9 corner and quickly following bolts out left.

content.description: Climb the corner (lieback) and traverse right at the top to the large tree.  Movement is good but the rock is a bit dirty.
content.protection: Standard trad rack.  Rap in from the tree (center left of formation) and climb out.
content.location: The route stars in the right facing book left of the clean face.

content.description: Begin approximately 15 feet north of the toe in the center of the crag at a small system of vertical crack. Work up and right to a bolt approximately in the middle and above the toe of the crag. Follow thin ledges and cracks past two more bolts to the top.
content.protection: Small gear is required to protect up to the 1st bolt .  Two additional bolts protect the crux moves.

content.description: This is a stellar single pitch climb on good rock.  The crux is around the single bolt at the top of the climb.
content.protection: Trad rack with an emphasis on small and medium gear (pro is a bit tricky).  Double ropes would be useful.  Rap in from the large tree and climb out.
content.location: The route starts on the clean face and climbs roughly straight up to a single bolt and the top.

content.description:
This is described as "a quality crag with a short approach" in the 'Sandia Select' guidebook by Mick Schein. In addition to the three routes in the guidebook:   a. 5.8 My Ass (5.8+)   b. Unknown (5.10d)   c. Unknown (5.9)   there is an additional bolted route ascending the arete to the left of route 'c'. 

  The routes are appoximately 150 ft with only a couple of bolts on the crux moves of routes 'a' and 'b'. The routes can also be top roped.
